title: Introduction to Programming
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces computer programming to students with no previous programming experience. Students learn how to design, implement, test, debug, and document programs. They also learn to solve problems using object-oriented programming methodology. Most of the examples and assignments will be related to genomics and bioinformatics.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. acquire the basic concept of computer programming b. design computer program using the Perl language c. apply computer program to solve simple bioinformatic questions
syllabus: Introduction to Computers and Programming;Programming with Python (The basics,Control structures, Functions and dictionaries,Classes and objects,Searching and regular expression); Python programming for bioinformatics with examples; Programming with R;Introduction to more high-level programming languages
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Introduction to Molecular Biology and Genetics
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces students to the molecular mechanisms responsible for the transmission, expression and regulation of genetic information in prokaryotic and eukaryotic organisms. Students will also learn the basic concepts of genetics including population genetics, developmental genetics and evolutionary genetics.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. understand basic concepts in biomolecules and cell biology b. know how molecular biology can explain the transmission of genetic information c. correlate molecular biology concepts with genetic and phenotypic traits
syllabus: Introduction to Biomolecules; Basic Cell Biology; DNA and Chromatin Structure; DNA Replication, Repair and Recombination; Control of Gene Expression; Methods in Molecular Biology; Genomic Applications in Biomedical Research; Molecular Genetics of Menedelian Diseases; Molecular Genetics of Complex Diseases; Population Genetics; Evolutionary Genetics
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: 1. Molecular Biology of the Cell, Fourth Edition by Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson 2. Human Molecular Genetics, Fourth Edition by Tom Strachan, Andrew Read

title: Bio-computing
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces the programming in Perl (Practical Extraction and Report Language). Students learn the Perl programming to address biological problems that involve nucleotide sequences, protein sequences and structure dataLetter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. know the functionality of tools deposited in the BioPerl b. combine modules in BioPerl to build bioinformatics applications c. develop bioinformatics-related modules using the Perl programming
syllabus: Introduction to computing environment; Basic Linux commands; Introduction to BioPerl; Common bioinformatics tools; Bio-statistics and processing biological data with R; Practices and review
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: UNIX and Linux System Administration Handbook (5th Edition). Addison-Wesley Professional. 2017

title: Genomics: Basic Concepts and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces the basic concepts of genomics. It covers the structure and organization of human genome, and the strategies that are used to map, sequence and analyse the genomes. Students learn how to make connections between genomic data and the relevant biological questions. They also learn how genomic sequence information is utilized biomedicine including pharmacogenomics, drug discovery, diagnostics and personalized medicine.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. acquire the basic concept of genomics b. learn the principle, strategies and limitations of genomic technology  c. apply genomics to solve biological and biomedical questions
syllabus: Introduction to genomics; An overview of large scale genomic projects; Genomic sequencing and data analysis; Genome assembly: a key step towards comprehensive genomic maps; Functional annotation of genomes: gene, mutation, and SNP; Workshop I & II; Functional annotation of genomes (transcriptional regulation, transcriptome analysis, noncoding RNA and single cell sequencing), Medical genomics
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Theories and Algorithms in Bioinformatics
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: The course introduces the basic concepts, methods and tools used in Bioinformatics. Students learn the structure and types of bioinformatics databases, sequence alignment and phylogeny, protein structure prediction, protein-protein interaction, molecular dynamics and other essential data mining algorithms. The major aim of this course is to equip the students to use bioinformatics tools to solve biological questions.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. learn the basic concept of bioinformatics b. know the theories and algorithms for database construction and data mining  c. apply bioinformatics tools to solve biological and biomedical questions
syllabus: Sequence Alignment and searching; Molecular phylogenetics; Molecular structures; Motifs and domains; Functional annotations; Processing and analysis of high-throughput data
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Systems Biology
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: This course introduces how systems biology combines molecular biology and genomics with physical chemistry and mathematical modeling to make bio-systems work. Students will learn basic concepts of nonlinear dynamics and genetic networks. They also learn mathematical modeling techniques needed to study biological questions and experiments that can be used to validate mathematical models.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. know the basic principle of systems biology b. learn how to apply control theory and genetic networks on genomics and bioinformatics  c. use systems biology to solve biological and biomedical questions
syllabus: Introduction to systems biology; Mathematical representations of cell biological systems I & II; Experimental methods in systems biology; Differential expression analysis I & II; Metabolic pathways and beyond; Network analysis I & II; Metabolic flux analysis; Case studies I & II
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: 1. A First Course in Systems Biology, 2nd edition. By Eberhard O. Voit. 2017. Garland Science.  2. Mathematical Modeling in Systems Biology: An Introduction. By Brian P. Ingalls. 2013. MIT Press.

title: Genome Informatics
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: The course introduces techniques and tools for gene prediction, genome annotation, gene expression profiling and comparative genomics. Special emphasis will be put on the manipulation of next-generation sequencing data and students will learn how to make use of such data to answer biological and biomedical questions.Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. know the techniques and tools for genome informatics  b. learn how to use these techniques and tools for manipulating next generation sequencing data c. apply these techniques and tools to solve biological and biomedical questions
syllabus: Overview of genome informatics; Sequencing to provide genome information; Genome assembly to obtain the reference genome; Reference genome based studies; Hands-on study on reference genome analysis; Resequencing to identify genomic variations; Genomic variation based studies (I) & (II); Hands-on study on resequencing analysis; Using genome sequencing as a tool for other researches; Using genome sequencing as a tool for applications; Summary of genome informatics
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.

title: Research Project
requirements: For students in MSc Genomics and Bioinformatics
description: Genome Informatics-related research topics will be provided by principal investigators in the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the Beijing Genome Institute Shenzhen in the first semester of the second year of study. After selecting the topics, students conduct the research in the second semester. Finally, they report their results in an oral presentation and submit a written report to the programme committee. Letter grades based on numeric scores will be given as the final academic grade of this course. Each grade is described as follows.
outcome: After finishing this course, students should be able to a. design the strategy and methodology to solve a research question  b. conduct experiments by implementing the research plan c. interpret and integrate experimental results to answer the research question d. present the research finding in the format of a written report and an oral presentation
syllabus: Each student is required to conduct a research project, submit a research proposal and a final report, and also give an oral presentation. Students and supervisors are matched subject to the mutual agreement.
required_readings: All required readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
recommended_readings: All recommended readings (if any) will be listed in the course outline given to students.
